issues.title: Missing Specific Superintendent Duties and Responsibilities
issues.description: California Education Code requires school districts to specify the superintendent's duties and responsibilities. While the policy provides general framework language, it lacks the specific statutory duties required by law, including instructional leadership, personnel management, budget responsibilities, and compliance oversight.

legal_citations.text: The governing board of any school district may delegate to any employee or employees of the district any of those duties and responsibilities other than those which by law may not be delegated.

issues.required_language:
The Superintendent's duties and responsibilities shall include, but not be limited to:
1. Serving as the educational leader and chief executive officer of the district
2. Implementing all policies adopted by the Board
3. Supervising the instruction and administration in the schools
4. Preparing and submitting recommendations for personnel appointments, assignments, promotions, and dismissals
5. Preparing the annual budget and making recommendations to the Board
6. Ensuring compliance with applicable laws, regulations, and Board policies
7. Serving as secretary to the Board of Education unless otherwise designated
8. Keeping the Board informed about district operations, issues, and opportunities
9. Representing the district in relationships with other agencies and the community

issues.title: Missing Administrative Regulation Document
issues.description: The policy references that superintendent responsibilities are detailed "throughout Board policies and administrative regulations," but no corresponding Administrative Regulation 2110 exists. This creates an incomplete policy framework and fails to provide the procedural "how" elements typically found in regulations.

legal_citations.text: On and after January 1, 1976, the governing board of any school district may initiate and carry on any program, activity, or may otherwise act in any manner which is not in conflict with or inconsistent with, or preempted by, any law and which is not in conflict with the purposes for which school districts are established.

issues.required_language:
Create Administrative Regulation 2110 to specify procedures for:
1. Annual goal-setting process between Board and Superintendent
2. Delegation of authority procedures
3. Reporting requirements and timelines
4. Communication protocols between Board and Superintendent
5. Emergency decision-making authority
6. Evaluation criteria and process details

issues.title: Missing Secretary to Board of Education Designation
issues.description: California law requires specification of who serves as secretary to the Board of Education. Most districts designate the superintendent unless otherwise specified, but this policy lacks any reference to this statutory requirement.

legal_citations.text: The governing board of each school district shall cause to be kept an accurate record of its proceedings. The secretary of the governing board, or in the absence of the secretary, the clerk, shall sign the minutes of each meeting.

issues.required_language: The Superintendent shall serve as secretary to the Board of Education unless the Board designates another individual to serve in this capacity. As secretary, the Superintendent or designee shall be responsible for maintaining accurate records of Board proceedings and ensuring proper documentation of all Board actions.

issues.title: Outdated Policy Review Date
issues.description: The policy was last reviewed in 2009, which is over 14 years ago. While not legally required, best practice recommends regular policy review cycles, especially for governance policies that may be affected by changing legal requirements.

legal_citations.text: The governing board of a school district shall review and update the policy manual of the school district as necessary, but not less than annually.

issues.required_language: Update the last reviewed date and establish a regular review cycle for this policy, ideally every 3-5 years or when significant legal changes occur.
